title: 2022 United States House of Representatives elections in Alabama
text:
The 2022 United States House of Representatives elections in Alabama will be held on November 8, 2022, to elect the seven <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives">U.S. Representatives</a> from the <a href="U.S.%20state">state</a> of <a href="Alabama">Alabama</a>, one from each of the state's seven <a href="Alabama%27s%20congressional%20districts">congressional districts</a>. The elections will coincide with <a href="United%20States%20House%20of%20Representatives%20elections%2C%202022">other elections</a> to the House of Representatives, <a href="2022%20United%20States%20Senate%20elections">elections</a> to the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> and various <a href="2022%20United%20States%20elections%23State%20elections">state</a> and <a href="2022%20United%20States%20elections%23Local%20elections">local elections</a>.
Background.
Following redistricting as a result of the <a href="2020%20United%20States%20census">2020 United States census</a>, the Republican-controlled <a href="Alabama%20Legislature">Alabama Legislature</a> adopted a new congressional map in the autumn of 2021. The map drew one of Alabama's seven congressional districts with an African-American majority population; a single African-American majority congressional district has been the case for over 30 years. Three federal judges denied this map on January 24, 2022, stating that Alabama, which has an African-American population of 27% as of 2022, needed two congressional districts that were likely to elect African-American representatives, in accordance with the <a href="Voting%20Rights%20Act%20of%201965">Voting Rights Act of 1965</a>. John Wahl, the chairman of the <a href="Alabama%20Republican%20Party">Alabama Republican Party</a>, said he expected the court's decision to be appealed. The office of the <a href="Attorney%20General%20of%20Alabama">Attorney General of Alabama</a> began the process of an appeal on January 25, 2022. The qualifying deadline for congressional candidates was also extended from January 28 to February 11.
"<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>" predicted that the appeal could go to the <a href="U.S.%20Supreme%20Court">U.S. Supreme Court</a> to address the practice of <a href="racial%20gerrymandering%20in%20the%20United%20States">racial gerrymandering in the United States</a>. If a second African-American majority district is upheld and passed, it would likely be a significant pick-up for Democrats in Alabama. In response to the federal ruling, Representative <a href="Jerry%20Carl">Jerry Carl</a> stated during a radio interview that his campaign was considering alternative strategies in the event that he was forced to run against fellow Representative <a href="Barry%20Moore%20%28Alabama%20politician%29">Barry Moore</a>. Chairman Wahl stated on January 28 that the Republican Party would plan to win all seven congressional seats if a new map created two competitive seats with slight African-American majorities, rather than one district guaranteed for a Democratic victory.
District 1.
The 1st district encompasses <a href="Washington%20County%2C%20Alabama">Washington</a>, <a href="Mobile%20County%2C%20Alabama">Mobile</a>, <a href="Baldwin%20County%2C%20Alabama">Baldwin</a>, <a href="Escambia%20County%2C%20Alabama">Escambia</a> and <a href="Monroe%20County%2C%20Alabama">Monroe</a> counties. The incumbent is Republican <a href="Jerry%20Carl">Jerry Carl</a>, who has represented the district since 2021 and was elected with 64.4% of the vote in 2020.
District 2.
The 2nd district encompasses most of the <a href="Montgomery%2C%20Alabama">Montgomery</a> metropolitan area, and stretches into the <a href="Wiregrass%20Region">Wiregrass Region</a> in the southeastern portion of the state, including <a href="Andalusia%2C%20Alabama">Andalusia</a>, <a href="Dothan%2C%20Alabama">Dothan</a>, <a href="Greenville%2C%20Alabama">Greenville</a>, and <a href="Troy%2C%20Alabama">Troy</a>. The incumbent is Republican <a href="Barry%20Moore%20%28Alabama%20politician%29">Barry Moore</a>, who was elected with 65.2% of the vote in 2020.
District 3.
The 3rd district is based in eastern Alabama, taking in small parts of <a href="Montgomery%2C%20Alabama">Montgomery</a>, as well as, <a href="Talladega%2C%20Alabama">Talladega</a>, <a href="Tuskegee%2C%20Alabama">Tuskegee</a> and <a href="Auburn%2C%20Alabama">Auburn</a>. The incumbent is Republican <a href="Mike%20Rogers%20%28Alabama%20politician%29">Mike Rogers</a>, who was re-elected with 67.5% of the vote in 2020.
District 4.
The 4th district is located in rural north-central Alabama, spanning the <a href="Bible%20Belt">Evangelical belt</a> area. The incumbent is Republican <a href="Robert%20Aderholt">Robert Aderholt</a>, who was re-elected with 82.2% of the vote in 2020.
District 5.
The 5th district is based in northern Alabama, including the city of <a href="Huntsville%2C%20Alabama">Huntsville</a>. The incumbent is Republican <a href="Mo%20Brooks">Mo Brooks</a>, who was re-elected with 95.8% of the vote in 2020, without major-party opposition. On March 22, 2021, Brooks announced his retirement and intention to run for U.S. Senate.
District 6.
The 6th district encompasses <a href="Birmingham%20metropolitan%20area%2C%20Alabama">Greater Birmingham</a>, taking in parts of <a href="Birmingham%2C%20Alabama">Birmingham</a>, as well as the surrounding suburbs, including <a href="Bibb%20County%2C%20Alabama">Bibb</a>, <a href="Blount%20County%2C%20Alabama">Blount</a>, <a href="Chilton%20County%2C%20Alabama">Chilton</a>, <a href="Coosa%20County%2C%20Alabama">Coosa</a>, and <a href="Shelby%20County%2C%20Alabama">Shelby</a> counties. The incumbent is Republican <a href="Gary%20Palmer%20%28politician%29">Gary Palmer</a>, who was re-elected with 97.1% of the vote in 2020, without major-party opposition.
District 7.
The 7th district encompasses the <a href="Black%20Belt%20%28region%20of%20Alabama%29">Black Belt</a>, including <a href="Selma%2C%20Alabama">Selma</a> and <a href="Demopolis%2C%20Alabama">Demopolis</a>, as well as taking in majority-black areas of <a href="Birmingham%2C%20Alabama">Birmingham</a>, <a href="Tuscaloosa%2C%20Alabama">Tuscaloosa</a>, and <a href="Montgomery%2C%20Alabama">Montgomery</a>. The incumbent is Democrat <a href="Terri%20Sewell">Terri Sewell</a>, who was re-elected with 97.2% of the vote in 2020, without major-party opposition.
